unnormalised: So, someone asked if online learning is any good in India, huh? Well, let me tell you, as a student who’s been through it all – from traditional classrooms to full-on online courses – it’s a mixed bag. It’s not a straight yes or no answer, you know? Depends on what you're looking for and which platform you choose.

Depends on what you're looking for and which platform you choose.

unnormalised: I started using BYJU'S last year for my class 10th maths, and honestly, it helped me score a solid 85% on the final exams. Earlier, I was barely scraping through with 60%! The interactive video lessons and personalized quizzes really worked for me. My friend, Rohan, swears by Vedantu for JEE prep; he says their master teachers are top-notch and he attends live classes at 7 PM every day.

My friend, Rohan, swears by Vedantu for J-E-E prep; he says their master teachers are top-notch and he attends live classes at seven P-M every day.

unnormalised: But it’s not all sunshine and rainbows. My cousin in Guwahati had a terrible experience with some random online course. Paid Rs. 10000 for it, and the quality was just…ugh. Recorded lectures from ages ago, no interaction, and the "teachers" were unresponsive. So, do your research properly before enrolling! Check reviews, ask around, and maybe even try a free trial first.

Check reviews, ask around, and maybe even try a free trial first.

unnormalised: The biggest advantage, I think, is the flexibility. You can learn at your own pace, whenever you want, wherever you want. I could study at 11 PM after finishing all my chores, or even during my train journeys. Plus, you save a lot of time on commuting and all. No more rushing to coaching classes after school!

unnormalised: So, in conclusion, online learning can be great, especially with platforms like Unacademy and Coursera, if done right. It helped me score well in 10th. Just be smart about it, do your homework, and don't fall for scams. Good luck!
